values.alignmentText: High environmental standards and abundant green spaces.
Moderate risk from floods and heatwaves.
Cold winters and mild summers with frequent clouds.
Generally good though some urban pollution.
Low major disaster threat but occasional flooding.
Northern coasts offer beaches though water is cool.
Swimmable mainly in late summer; otherwise chilly.
Forests, Alps, and the Rhine valley provide scenery.
Solid national minimum wage supports basic living.
Good pay in Berlin and Munich though taxed heavily.
Enterprises widely use .NET creating steady demand.
Active startup scene especially in Berlin.
EU Blue Card makes skilled immigration feasible.
Strong export economy with stable growth.
Remote work accepted though offices remain common.
Protected leisure time and clear boundaries.
Standard 35-40 hour weeks with overtime limits.
At least 20 days statutory leave plus holidays.
Four to six weeks common in tech roles.
Efficient yet not hectic; slower in smaller towns.
Generous parental leave and child benefits.
Small communities with limited social recognition.
Structured education with moderate extracurricular demands.
Playgrounds and safe infrastructure widespread.
Quality public schools and bilingual options in cities.
Engineering culture and rich history.
English widely taught but German needed for daily life.
Socially liberal with strong welfare state.
Left-wing parties present though capitalism dominant.
Secular trend especially in the east.
Generally open-minded but not explicit.
Legal protections and growing acceptance.
Reserved at first but dependable once connected.
Values efficiency and environmental consciousness.
Collaborative within EU though mindful of history.

values.key: View of Them by Neighboring Countries
values.alignmentText: Seen as economic leader, occasionally dominant.
Fairly egalitarian though traditional in some regions.
Legal recognition exists with improving social acceptance.
Strong laws on equality and parental leave.
Practical fashion and independence valued.
Work ethic and reliability emphasized.
Hiking, football, and car culture.
Major board game hub with events like Spiel.
Vibrant scenes in Berlin and Hamburg.
Active tech and maker meetups across cities.
Forests and countryside easily reached by train.
Federal parliamentary republic with coalition governance.
Limited church influence on policy.
Strong protections and codetermination.
Social market economy balancing welfare and markets.
Universal statutory health insurance.
Mandatory coverage with good access.
Subsidized Kita programs though shortages exist.
Benefits and parental leave support families.
Low risk with strong institutions.
Regulated capitalism with strong SMEs.
High-quality vocational and university systems.
Economically and politically stable.
Free press with minimal propaganda.
Public broadcasters emphasize civic responsibility.
Progressive labor and social welfare policies.
Moderate to high trust levels.
Low corruption levels overall.
Occasional political or corporate scandals.
High rents in major cities but strong tenant protections.
Extensive rail and urban transit networks.
Generally safe with low violent crime.
Social market economy.
Pension access with contributions; aging population challenges.
PAYE with annual adjustments; can be complex.
Higher tax rates with social contributions.
Modern though cash is still common.
Moderate overall; high in Munich or Frankfurt.
EU Blue Card and job seeker visas available.
Generally positive for skilled workers.
Temporary permits lead to permanent residence after several years.
Naturalization after 6-8 years; dual citizenship limited.
Spouses get work rights and children receive benefits.
Processing times moderate with reasonable fees.
Must maintain registration and health insurance.
Growing industry with government support.
Crytek, Daedalic, and Ubisoft Blue Byte operate here.
Events like Gamescom foster community.
Funding schemes like the German Games Fund aid startups.
Reliable utilities and high-speed autobahns.
